review.title: Interference Effects in Quantum Belief Networks
review.abstract: Probabilistic graphical models such as Bayesian Networks are one of the most powerful structures known by the Computer Science community for deriving probabilistic inferences. However, modern cognitive psychology has revealed that human decisions could not follow the rules of classical probability theory, because humans cannot process large amounts of data in order to make judgements. Consequently, the inferences performed are based on limited data coupled with several heuristics, leading to violations of the law of total probability. This means that probabilistic graphical models based on classical probability theory are too limited to fully simulate and explain various aspects of human decision making.

sections.text: The quantum probability theory was developed to account for the paradox results that the classical theory could not explain. Recent findings in cognitive psychology showed that the quantum probability can fully describe human decisions within an elegant framework. Their results suggest that human thoughts, before making a decision, are considered as overlapping waves that can mutually influence each other and influence the final decision. In this work, we propose a new Bayesian network based on the psychological insights of cognitive scientists. We conducted experiments with two very well-known Bayesian networks from literature. The results obtained showed that quanta such as the Eyesian network can drastically influence the probable conclusions, especially when the level of uncertainty of the network is very high (no evidence is observed). sections.heading: 1.3 Outline
sections.text: Before describing the proposed model, we must first present some quantum probability concepts for understanding this work. Sections 2 and 3 describe the main differences between classical theory and quantum probability theory. Instead of presenting just a series of formulas, we show this difference using a graphic example, just as suggested in [17]. Section 4 describes how beliefs act like waves and can influence each other. Section 6 shows mathematically how this concept of interference can be derived by using well-known rules of complex numbers. Section 5 deals with the major works of literature that have contributed to the development of the concept of interference. It also introduces a new interference formula that is applied to the proposed quantum probability graphical models. Section 6 presents a comparison between a classical Bayesian network model and the proposed quantum interference model, Section 11 presenting the main results of Bayesian network interference theory to the problem of two-stage gambling. Section 7 presents a further comparison between classical and quantum interference models.

sections.heading: 2 Probability Axioms of Classical and Quantum Theory
sections.text: In this section, we describe the main differences between classical theory and quantum probability theory using examples. The example analyzed concerns the duty of the jury. Suppose you are a jury and must decide whether a suspect is guilty or innocent. The following sections describe how classical theory and quantum theory develop in the subsequent trial.

sections.heading: 2.1 Space
sections.text: In classical probability theory, events are contained in example rooms. An example room corresponds to the totality of all possible results of an experiment or a random trial. [31] In assessing whether a suspect is guilty or innocent, the example room is represented by Figure 5, which represents the example room of a defendant as guilty or innocent.In quantum probability theory, events are contained in the so-called Hilbert spaces.A Hilbert space H can be considered a generalization and expansion of Euclidean space into spaces with any finite or infinite number or dimension. It can be considered a vector space of complex numbers and provides the structure of an inner product to allow the measurement of angles and lengths [40]. Space is spanned by a series of orthonormal vectors H = {guilty, innocent}. Together, these vectors form a basis for space. Figure 6 represents a part representing a guilty space or another space that is normally innocent.

sections.heading: 2.2 Events
sections.text: In classical probability theory, events can be defined by a set of results to which a probability is assigned. They correspond to a subset of the sample space in which they are contained. Events can be mutually exclusive and they obey set theory. This means that operations such as the intersection or unification of events are well defined. Since they respect set theory, the distribution axiom is also defined between sets. In our example, they can be regarded as two mutually exclusive events. According to quantum probability theory, events correspond to a subspace spanned by a subset of the base vectors contained in Hilbert space. Events can be orthogonal, that is, they can be mutually exclusive. Operations such as intersection and unification of events are well defined when the events are spanned by the same base vector. [17] In quantum theory, all events contained in a Hilbert space are defined by a superlative state.

sections.heading: 2.3 System State
sections.text: A system state is nothing more than a probability function Pr, which maps events in probability numbers, i.e. positive real numbers between 0 and 1. In classical theory, the system state exactly corresponds to its definition. There is a function that is responsible for assigning a probability value to the result of an event. If the event matches the sample space, the system state assigns a probability value of 1 to the event. If the event is empty, it assigns a probability of 0 to the event. In our example, the juror is not told otherwise, then the probability that the defendant is guilty is Pr (guilty) = 0.5. In quantum theory, the probability that a suspect is guilty is given by the square size of the projection from the superposition state S into the subspace containing the observed event. Figure 8 shows an example. If the juror is not told anything about the guilt of a defendant, then, according to quantum theory, we start with an overlay of the state S in the subspace in which the observed event is going on.

sections.heading: 2.4 State Revision
sections.text: State revision corresponds to the situation in which, after observing an event, we are interested in observing other events since the previous event occurred. In classical theory, this is determined by the conditional probability formula Pr (B | A) = Pr (A) B) Pr (B). So, suppose that evidence has been presented to the jury proving that the defendant is indeed guilty, what is the probability that he is innocent? This is calculated as follows: Pr (innocent | guilty) = Pr (innocent) Pr (guilty) = 0Since the events are mutually exclusive, their intersection is empty, resulting in a zero probability value. In quantum theory, state revision is given by first projecting the surveillance state S into the subspace representing the observed event, and then normalizing the projection so that the resulting vector has a unit length.

sections.heading: 4 The Interference Term
sections.text: Quantum theory allows the modeling of the decision system as a wave moving through a state space until a final decision is made. Interference can be considered from this perspective as a chain of waves in an overlay state coming from different directions. When these waves collide, one can experience a destructive effect (one wave destroys the other) or a constructive effect (one wave merges with another), in both cases affecting the final probabilities of each wave. Psychological findings showed that this happens not only on a microscopic scale (such as electrons), but also in a macroscopic environment [44, 61, 22]. In this section, we will show how to derive the concept of interference by taking into account only known properties of complex numbers [48]. The concept of interference can be derived in two different ways: (1) from the general formula of probability of unification of N mutually exclusive events and (2) from the total law of probability.

sections.heading: 6.1 Classical Bayesian Networks
sections.text: A classical Bayesian network can be defined by a directed acyclic graph structure in which each node represents a different random variable of a particular domain and each edge represents a direct influence from the source node to the target node. The graph represents independence relations between variables and each node is associated with a conditional probability table that determines a distribution over the values of a node in any possible common assignment of values of its parents. This notion of a node that depends directly on its parent nodes is the core of Bayesian networks. Once the values of the parents are known, no information that directly or indirectly refers to its parents or other ancestors can influence beliefs about it [49].

sections.heading: 6.1.1 Classical Conditional Independece
sections.text: Two random variables X and Y are conditionally independent vis-à-vis a third random variable Z, if and only if they are independent in their conditional probability distribution. In other words, X and Y are conditionally independent vis-à-vis Z, (X = x-Y = y-Z) if and only if the probability distribution of X is equal for all values of Y and the probability distribution of Y is equal for all values of X. This means that a declaration of independence via random variables is a universal quantification of all possible values of random variables [49]. sections.heading: 10 Related Work
sections.text: From the preliminary results of [69], cognitive scientists began to use alternative theories such as quantum probability theory to explain the paradoxical results that classical probability theory could not explain. Given the flexibility of the quantum probabilistic framework, several researchers applied these concepts in various areas outside physics. In this section, we will present some of the topics where quantum probability has had some impact in the literature.

sections.heading: 10.1 Violations of Probability Theory
sections.text: In terms of violations of the theory of probability, there are many paradoxical situations in which the classical probability cannot be modeled, the most important paradoxes being violations of the ure thing principle. Examples of such violations correspond to the Ellsberg paradox [32], the two-step gambling [71, 50, 51] and the prisoner's quantum dynamic game [71, 26, 54, 18, 41, 25]. With respect to the prisoner's quantum mechanical quantum game, many papers have been proposed in the literature formalizing the problem in a quantum approach. For example, [61] a quantum dynamic Markov model for the prisoner's quantum mechanical game suggested. In their model, the authors represented the belief and actions of the players as overlapping in a quantum state vector. If the player knew the information about the opponent's action, the supercharge state collapsed into a new state that was compatible with the opponent's action.

sections.heading: 10.2 Conjunction and Diskunction Errors
sections.text: Other situations in which the laws of probability are violated correspond to disjunction or conjunction errors. A conjunction error occurs when specific conditions are assumed to be more likely than a single general one. A disjunction error, on the other hand, consists in the assumption that the disjunction of two events is at least as likely as one of the two events separately. Several papers in the literature have used quantum probability models to explain these errors. [34] For example, a quantum probabilistic model has been developed to explain errors when preferences are made to a series of events, more precisely, the conjunction fallacy. [19] The authors also focused on quantum models to explain the conjunction and [26] focused on disjunction fallacies. The first experiments in which these errors were observed were conducted by [71]. An alternative model for conjunction and disjunction errors corresponds to [70]. The authors used support theory to make a subjective model of probability that describes perceptions as most probable.

sections.heading: A A Grid Search Approach to Find Quantum Parameters
sections.text: The most naive approach to parameter search is the grid search method. In this approach, a grid is placed over the parameter space and the data is evaluated at each grid intersection and the parameters that lead to the maximum performance of an algorithm are returned. [55] However, the grid search has the problem of being unlimited, since an unlimited number of parameters are available to be tested. In the context of this work, this is not a problem, because we always have a limit. The values of a cosine function can all be specified for angles between the range [0,2π]. metadata.abstractText: Probabilistic graphical models such as Bayesian Networks are one of the most powerful structures known by the Computer Science community for deriving probabilistic inferences. However, modern cognitive psychology has revealed that human decisions could not follow the rules of classical probability theory, because humans cannot process large amounts of data in order to make judgements. Consequently, the inferences performed are based on limited data coupled with several heuristics, leading to violations of the law of total probability. This means that probabilistic graphical models based on classical probability theory are too limited to fully simulate and explain various aspects of human decision making. Quantum probability theory was developed in order to accommodate the paradoxical findings that the classical theory could not explain. Recent findings in cognitive psychology revealed that quantum probability can fully describe human decisions in an elegant framework. Their findings suggest that, before taking a decision, human thoughts are seen as superposed waves that can interfere with each other, influencing the final decision. In this work, we propose a new Bayesian Network based on the psychological findings of cognitive scientists. We made experiments with two very well known Bayesian Networks from the literature. The results obtained revealed that the quantum like Bayesian Network can affect drastically the probabilistic inferences, specially when the levels of uncertainty of the network are very high (no pieces of evidence observed). When the levels of uncertainty are very low, then the proposed quantum like network collapses to its classical counterpart.
